div.p: Alarm for London, or the siege of Antwerp. With the venturous acts and valorous deeds of the lame soldier. As it hath been played by the right honourable the lord chamberlain his servants.
London, printed for William Ferbrand, and are to be sold at his shop in Popes-head alley, over against the tavern door, near the Royal-exchange. 1602.

div.head: Prologus.
div.l: Round through the compass of this earthly ball,
The massy substance hanging in the sky,
Hath fleeting time pursued this froward age;
And searched the world's corrupt enormities.
Here found I some, despite my hoary scalp,
There sound I courtiers laughed my course to scorn,
In that place dainty mouthed damsels scoff,
Sticking my feathers with their borrowed plumes,
As though my beauty were not good enough.
And now this fair concourse here met together,
That have calm leisure to behold their faults,
Within my furrowed bosom deep ingrained:
Like a steel forged impression (Fixed firm)
Are met together: you will scorn my wants,
Laugh at my lament, look basely, fume and frown
But do so, do so, your proud eyes shall see
The punishment of city cruelty:
And if your hearts be not of adamant,
Reform the mischief of degenerat minds,
And make you weep in pure relenting kind.

div.head: A alarm for London, or the siege of Antwerp: with the virtuous acts and valorous deeds of the same soldier.
div.stage: Enter Sancto Danila and two other captains.

sp.speaker: Dani.
sp.l: So, leave me now, and in mine absence, see
That not a soldier perch upon the walls;
Lest by the citizens they be espied,
And thereupon they grow suspicious,
Be gone, and give the sentinels in charge,
They have an eye unto the Southern port:
And hear ye? if that any forces come,
Let them be straight received into the castle,
But with as little tumult as you may.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: It shall be done my lord.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: We must be secret, as befits the care,
And expedition of so great a cause;
Antwerp is wealthy, but withal secure,
Our soldiers want the crowns they surfeit with,
And therefore she must spare from forth her store,
To help her neighbours; nay she shall be forced,
To strip her of her pouches, and on the backs
Of Spanish soldiers, hang her costliest robes.
The plot already is determined of,
And say Cornelius do but keep his word;
These swilling epicures shall taste of death,
whilst we survive to rifle their rich coffers.
Here comes the man, welcome Cornelius,
I see you make religion of your word.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Speak softly good my lord lest ye be heard,
The citizens are scouting here about.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Not one Gernelius dare approach so near,
The castle shot keeps them in greater awe,
And for discovery by the eye, fear not;
Within this valley we may talk at large,
And no man see us: say are you resolved,
To stand firm friend unto the Spaniard?
And sancto Damla vows you shall partake,
Both spoil and honour with the best of us.

sp.speaker: Co●.
sp.l: Suppose my lord I gave you my consent,
In all the world there's not (At my command)
Above six hundred Almains; you yourself,
Are in the castle scarce a thousand strong,
And what are these to sack so great a town?
So populous and large as Antwerp is.
The citizens (Were they but politic,
Careful and studious to preserve their peace)
Might an hours warning, fill their streets,
With forty thousand well appointed soldiers.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Ay, but they are remiss and negligent,
Their bodies used to soft effeminate silks,
And their nice minds set all on dalliance;
Which makes them fat for slaughter, fit for spoil:
But say 'twere otherwise that in their peace
And days of plenty, whilst they flourished
They had foreseen the danger might ensue,
And exercise themselves in feats of arms;
Yet we being sole commander of the castle,
And that commanding them, what let is there,
(Were we much weaker) but we might prevail?
When once the a alarm sounds (Like silly mice)
They'll hide them in the crevice of their walls,
And some for ignorance, will stand amazed;
And some will be so tender of their flesh,
As they will scorn to bear the weight of steel,
No, no brave Almaigne if men ever had
A fit occasion to enrich themselves,
And fill the vast world with their echoing fame;
Now is that instant put into our hands;
And now may we be lords of this proud town ▪
My mind divines no less, and till my feet
Tread a venturous measure in their streets,
I shall be sick to think upon the deed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I wish my lord as much as you detain,
But such an enterprise must be well grounded,
Lest in performance there be found defect.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: What patient eye can look upon yond turrets,
And see the beauty of that flower of Europe,
And in't be ravished with the sight of her?
O she is amorous as the wanton air.
And must be courted: from her no 〈◊〉 comes
A breath, as sweet as the Arabian spice.
Her garments are embroidered with pure gold;
And every part so rich and sumptuous,
As India's not to be compared to her,
She must be courted, ●ary herself invites,
And beckons us unto her sportful bed;
What is he then more lumpish than rude iron,
By such a lodestar may not be attempted?
O brave Cornelius, if within thy veins,
There be that heat of vallout? I presume;
Let us forslow no time till we obtain
To revel in that bower of earthly bliss.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My lord, what lies in me ye shall dispose,
My regiment of Almains, and myself,
Will on the first assault revolt to you;
mean space I'll give you close intelligence,
Of any thing the citizens pretend:
But as I said, what makes this to the spoil,
Of such a might city as this is,
Unless we be confirmed with more supply?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Behold this scroll and be resolved in that,
From Mastricht first there comes a thousand horse,
Beside five hundred foot: under the guiding
Of don Alonzo de Verdugo: then
From L●yre doth 〈◊〉 de Romero, bring
Five hundred foot; from Aelst two thousand more
Follow the conduct of Emanuel;
The Duke of Alva likewise brings his power,
And for a better colour, to delude
These credulous inhabitants of Antwerp,
He causeth it be published he is dead,
And that his soldiers guard his body hither,
To have it shipped for Spain to be interred:
Which well may serve to shadow his approach,
The rest by night shall have their entrance;
So that within two days I make account,
We shall be gathered to a perfect head,
Of (At the least) six thousand Spaniards.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I marry my lord, this soundeth somewhat like,
Now dares Cornelius promise victory.
But how intends your lordship to begin,
And give an entrance to this business?
You know th' Antwerpians never yet took part,
In any action 'gainst his majesty,
But have remained as neutral, neither aiding
The prince of Orange nor offending you:
How will you then enkindle flames of war,
And take occasion to commence your quarrel?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Why any way; it shall be thus Cornelius,
I'll charge the master gunner of the castle,
To make a shot or two upon the town;
and when they come to know the cause of it,
I'll say it was, because they do not sink,
The prince of Orange ships: but suffer them
To lie so near within the liver 〈◊〉,
Which not withstanding, we precisely know,
Do hover there about, to no end else,
But to safe conduct victuals to the town.
Yet this excuse will serve to cloak our ha●e,
And show some reason for what after follows.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It cannot be but good my noble lord,
And shortly (As their daily custom is)
Changing the governor and other burghers,
Intend a solemn banquet at the statehouse.
Even then, and at that place, give you direction,
The gunner take his level, 'twill affright,
And strike the greater terror to their souls.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Enough, I'll play them music to their meat,
And send such revellers into the room,
As some of them shall have caroused their last,
The most I crave, is that Cornelius
Will be as constant as he hath professed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Once more my lord I gauge my hand with yours,
And as he is a soldier and a knight,
Cornelius vows to be a friend to Spain.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I take thy word fair knight, and back again
Return the like to thee; both I and mine,
For ever vow to love and honour thee:
Now break we off our secret conference,
And closely as we came unto this place,
So let us circumspectly make retreat.
Walk thou into the town as if thou hadst
But only come abroad to take the air.
I to the castle will withdraw myself
Down some back way, and ever as we need,
Be this our meeting place, till Antwerp bleed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Farewell my lord, Cornelius is agreed.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: What ordinance have you laden on that part:

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: A falcon and two harguebuz of crock.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: What tellst thou me of harguebuz of crock?
A pox upon your rascal squibs and crackers,
Have you been loading all this day till now,
And come you with your harguebuz of crock?
A plague upon't.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: My lord, blame your direction: nevertheless,
Not full assured of your lordship's pleasure,
We have raised the cannons that came last from Harlam,
And planted them this morning for the purpose.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: 'Twas well advised; but gunner for what part?

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: That's as it please your honour to direct,

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: That's for the statehouse gunner, where the Dutch
Sit swilling in the pride of their excess;
Commend us to them, tell them we have sent
Music to make them merry at their feast:
Go bid thy full-mouthed cannon ▪ much good do't them.
Should we discharge some scurvy culvering,
They'll think we are about some firework,
To make them sport with.
For sure they fall asleep upon full stomachs,
Shoot me their statehouse through both the sides,
And tell them thou didst it for their health,
To keepe them waking.

sp.speaker: Gun.
sp.l: I warrant you my lord, I'll pierce her sides,
Or never think me workman whilst I live.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I will not stir till I have heard the shot.
Go light thy lintstock at some hellish brand,
To send black vengeance to that hated town;
Let every corn of powder be a spirit,
Thy mortal aim as ominous as death,
And never a splinter that the bullet strikes,
but let it prove a very murdering piece,
Amongst the burghers at their banqueting,
To vomit horrid plagues upon them all.
There be thou like the club of Hercules,
Amongst the bousing Bacchanalian centures,
To beat their Rhenish cans about their ears.
Good luck I hope hark how the sudden noise
In countering with the cannon's loud report,
Stops his full mouth, with the reverberate sound,
And fills the circle of the empty air.

sp.speaker: 1 Bur.
sp.l: The shot what from the castle questionless.

sp.speaker: 2 Bur.
sp.l: The smoke and the report may tell you so.

sp.speaker: 1 Bur.
sp.l: And certainly intended at our lives.

sp.speaker: 2 Bur.
sp.l: Call to the governor.

sp.speaker: 1 Bur.
sp.l: He's walking here without the castle stay:,
The citizens have sent me to demand,
On what occasion, or by whose commandment,
You have discharged this shot upon the town?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: At my command sir, what is that to you?

sp.speaker: 2 Bur.
sp.l: Then thy command (I tell thee sancto Danila)
Is devilish and unchristian;
Which passing through the statehouse of the city,
Hath slain three persons.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Three frothy Rhenish fats that have drunk dead,
Or in their cups have fallen to cutting throats,
And fearing that it would be noised abroad,
To cover your foul bestial gourmandize,
Give it out to be a shot sent from the castle.

sp.speaker: 1 Bur.
sp.l: That men are slain we'll not expostulate,
But governor, was it by your commandment?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Tell me you men of Antwerp,
If you do startle at a cannon's burst,
why suffer you the prince of Orange ships,
To ride upon the river at their pleasure?
And with their fleering tops to mock our fames,
The whilst the sconces which do flank the river,
Serve but for fishers to unload their nets;
Whilst cankering rust, devours your empty cannons:
And they lie hulling up and down the stream?
Burghers of Antwerp answer me to this.

sp.speaker: 2 Bur.
sp.l: They be of Zealand, and the prince of Orange
Hath ever been a friend unto the state.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: But enemy unto the King my master;
Therefore they shall not ride upon the river;
Which if your own security do suffer,
We'll make our bandogs to awake your town.

sp.speaker: 1 Bur.
sp.l: Is that the cause and reason of your shot?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Burger it is.

sp.speaker: 2. Bur.
sp.l: You should have sent us word of your dislike:

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Why so we did, did we not send our post
Even now unto you?
And wrapped our packet in a ball of lead?
I think we sent a bold ambassador.
That spoke our mind in thunder: did he not?
You might before have known of our dislike,
But that we did perceive you would not see,
'Twas well you heard of us.
sp.stage: A signet sounded, enter two with mourning pennons: a Drum sounding a dead march: Dalva carried upon a horse covered with black: soldiers after, trailing their pikes.
sp.l: No citizens of Antwerp, this the cause
That makes you careless and neglect our power,
The death of princely Dalva, had he lived,
The fleet of Orange had not traded thus,
Nor braved our castle.

div.stage: Enter two or three citizens running.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: I pray God they mean not to assault the town.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: 'Tis Dalva's body brought unto the castle.

sp.speaker: 3 citizen
sp.l: I would he had come thus, when he came first
Into these countries.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: So would I, what's become of this damned fiend?

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: Let the devil look to that, for he has most right to him.

sp.speaker: 3 citizen
sp.l: I would the cow hide were off, we might see the four quarters.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: A plague go with him.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: There will be old triumphing in hell.

sp.speaker: 3 citizen
sp.l: There will be old supping of boiling lead.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: That Dalva was a bloody villain.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: He was worse than the Spanish inquisition.

sp.speaker: 3 citizen
sp.l: Well, if ever man would have eaten up the cannibals, 'twas he.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: I fear nothing but one.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: That the people will curse him out of's grave.

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: I am glad they have cursed him into it.

sp.speaker: 3 citizen
sp.l: Well, it was never heard that Dalva was dead,
But there was some notable villainy followed it.

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: What dost thou think he will revive again?

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: If do, the devil's on't, I'll never trust death on's word for a half penny.

sp.speaker: 3 citizen
sp.l: Come, we'll mourn in sack for him.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Come, let's retire ourselves into the statehouse,
'Tis Dalva's body brought into the castle.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: March nearer to the castle with your hearse,
Before you set it down.

sp.speaker: Alu. in the hearse.
sp.l: What are those villains gone that railed upon me?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: They are my lord.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Set down and let me light,
sp.stage: He comes from under the hearse.
sp.l: I would not hear myself again so railed on,
Not for half Belgia.
Zounds the dog's bark at me, a plague upon them all,
I think they do not hate the devil so;
Dalva is never named but with a curse,
Think but these rogues, this is a time to die,
And hear these damned dogs revile me thus:
Well I am dead, but Alva's spirit (Ere long)
Shall haunt your ghosts, and with a fatal troop,
Come in the dreadful night about your walls,
Grim death did ne'er affright the fearful martial,
As I will fright these bousing Begians:
Who's that above? Lord 〈◊〉 Danila?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: My lord of Alva; enter the castle.
sp.stage: Enter Alonzo Verdugo, and his soldiers with a still march.
sp.l: O the lord Verdugo, and his regiment,
From Mastricht? 'tis well.
sp.stage: Enter Julian Romero, and his power with a still march.
sp.l: Julian Romero and his regiment from Leyre?
My lord Romero where is don Emanuel?
To bring the power that we expect from Alst.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: Who's that? Lord sancto Danila?
He's entered on the other side the castle,
Withal his power.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Not yet full ten, my mind presageth good,
Antwerp ere night, shall bathe herself in blood.

div.stage: Enter Marquess d'hawrye, Egmount, champagne, van end and his page: English governor and one Burger.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Monsieur champagne, great Antwerp's governor,
Will you refuse these fair and fresh supplies?
Sent from the prince of Orange and the states,
Under our conduct for your city's guard?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Lord marquess Hawrye, we reject them not,
Nor yet neglect the love of that great prince,
And our kind friend the co-united states:
But since we have no need of such a power,
Why should we pester Antwerp with such troops,
To spend the victuals of the citizens,
Which we can scarcely compass now for gilt.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: The prince and states will furnish ye with store,
To feed the army and relieve the town.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: And it may not be so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Outwords and honours be engaged for it.

sp.speaker: Eng. governor
sp.l: Under correction my lord governor,
The marks and count Egmont's noble words,
(Although the prince of Orange and the states
Should be forgetful) were a pawn of worth.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What says the colonel of the Almains to it?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: This is van ends opinion my good lord,
That the rich promise of such noble peers,
As marquess Hanurie and count Egmont are,
Is pawn enough for all the city's wealth.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: The almain lies, wealth is worth more than words.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I way their promise with my sound belief,
And tie my thoughts to their assured trust,
Yet are there many reasons of import,
To bar your army's entrance to this town.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: The grand objection is decided.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: The lesser than are easily refelled.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Suppose the prince and states do victual them,
Yet their disorder in our civil streets,
May be pernicious, and breed mutiny.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By this supposal you enfeeble us,
and tax our worth with indiscretion,
As though our skill and our authority,
Stood upon bases of weak discipline.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: We said not so, and yet their ryotings,
May taint our wives and jeopardise our wealth.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: In silence be it my lord, you need them not.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: All riots shall be death by martial law,
And all commanders, shall be vigilent
Over their troops, that order may he kept.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: My lords of Egmount and of Hauurye,
What are your numbers?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Just 3000, foot,
One thousand horse, 800. at the least.

sp.speaker: Eng governor
sp.l: An honourable tender of true friends,
To send such aid for safeguard of your city.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: 'Twill will shake our bags too much to pay so many.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: At whose expense shall all this army rest?

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: Some part yourselves, some part the prince will pay.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Six hundred Almains are our garrison,
A guard sufficient to defend our walls,
And men enough, because we need no more.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: And they too many to be paid by us.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: O may these slaves refuse this succour sent,
Their misery shall bring their misery.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Count Egmont, surely Antwerp is bewitched,
Security hath slain their providence,
And riches makes them reckless of their friends;
We must assume the charge upon ourselves,
And pray the prince and states to bear the pay;
Or else their private avarice, will pull
Public destruction on this flower of towns,
To the disgrace of all the Netherlands.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: I will make tender of so much to them,
Two months the prince of Orange and the states,
And we ourselves, will pay four thousand men:
If afterwards, our powers be not of use,
we shall withdraw them to their provinces,
May this content you curious citizens?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The offer is so honourable now,
As modestly, we cannot challenge it:
Captain Cornelius what's your counsel?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: This:
Say, that you fear the Spaniards will conceive
Some high displeasure, if you take them in,
My lords these fat pursed peasants are so proud,
Friends and defence, are less esteemed than pelf.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Governor of Antwerp, how are you resolved?

sp.speaker: Cham
sp.l: My lords, the prince of Orange and yourselves,
And all the states deserve our duteous love
And humble service: first, for sending power,
Then promising pay and victuals for that power:
But with your pardon, yet there is a let,
That makes us loath to take your army in.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: What let champagne?

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: The Spanish governor,
Danila, commander of the castle here,
If we receive your troops into our town,
Will judge we have some purpose of revolt,
And raising arms against the King of Spain.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What if he do?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: His fiery spirit inflamed,
Will send our bullets from the citadel,
And tear the sumptuous buildings of our town.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: As late he did when we were banqueting,
And thought no harm, but drinking health to health,
He shot, and slew some innocent poor souls,
And rent our statehouse and some buildings else.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: He'll rend you better if our purpose hold.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: What was the cause?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Because we did not sink,
The prince of Orange ships, that lay to waft
Provision to our city up the river.

sp.speaker: Eng. Gover.
sp.l: Observe by that you discreet governors,
What love or faith the Spaniard holds with you,
That for his pride would have your city pine;
Having destroyed the corn on Flanders side,
And crossed a bridge of convoy to your town;
Then that the river should not victual you,
He wished you sink that shipping in the skelt.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: Collect by this the Spaniards cruelty,
Who though occasion should not come from you,
Would pick a quarrel for occasion,
To sack your city, and to suck your blood,
To satisfy his pride and luxury:
Let Harlem ▪ Mastricht, Alst example you,
And many city's models of his wrath,
Think on my father and the county horn,
Whose tragedy, if I recount with ruth,
May move the stones of Antwerp to relent ▪
They served the Spaniard as his liegemen sworn,
Yet, for they did but wish their country good,
He picked a quarrel, and cut off their heads.
Burghers the Spaniard waits to take your lives,
That he may spoil your town, your wealth, your wives

sp.speaker: Eng. governor
sp.l: Receive your friends, prevent his treachery,
Lest unawares you taste his tyranny.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What benefit (Good countrymen) gain we,
That prostitute our fortunes and our blood,
In your defence?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Say, shall we let them in?

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: In troth I think the Spaniard means no harm.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Mean what he may, we'll not offend such friends,
As these, the prince of Orange and the state,
Your army is at Kibdorpe port you say?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There stay our forces.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: We will let them in,
And quarter them with all convenient speed,
Van end draw up your Almains to one place,
and keep good rule for fear of civil braules,
And now my lords I will attend on you.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I will attend to look and guard my doors,
And keep my wealth, my wife, and daughter safe,
For fear these hungry soldiers get a snatch.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Younker come here, haste to the castle wall,
And call to speak with sancto Danila,
Tell him from me, the flies begin to swarm ▪
The sun grows hot, the herds do shake their horns,
The shepherds bring great flocks home to the fold;
Say, if the butcher slaughter not in time,
The beasts will surfeit, and the soldiers pine,
Therefore begin before one glass be run,
And we shall win ere setting of the sun:
Remember this, be secret and away.
Now (Antwerp) comes the Spaniards holiday,
With them join I, my share is in the gold,
I run with the hare, and with the hound I hold;
This Sunday shall be dismal to the town,
The burghers die, their gallant wiues gone down.

div.stage: As he is going out stump encounters him.
Enter Burger, champagne, and their wives.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Afore good wife, I fear that all's not well,
Monsieur champagne what's your opinion?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Doubtless, the Spaniards do intend some hurt,
Hark how the tumult still increaseth?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: For shame,
Be not so fearful, say that for some offence,
Either commenced, or but in conceit;
The Spaniards were maliciously inclined:
Have ye not soldiers to withstand their force?
What should you need to be solicitous,
keep ye 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Nay wife thou dost mistake,
If thou imagine we intend to fight;
'Tis not 〈…〉 at the charge
To pay 〈…〉 should not they
Be at the care to see the city safe.

sp.speaker: 2 wife
sp.l: The city's safe enough without their care,
Will you to dinner?

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Wherefore shoot they thus,
Unless there were some villainy abroach?

sp.speaker: 2 wife
sp.l: Wherefore shoot they but to try their pieces,
I warrant you husband 'tis no otherwise.

div.stage: Enter Marquess with his sword drawn.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Here comes the marks he can tell the news.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: The cause my lord of this intestine uproar?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The cause is murder, misery and death:
You men of Antwerp, if with all the speed
And expedition, that in men remains,
You take not weapons to repulse the foe,
That like a swarm of deadly stinging hornets,
Have all this while lay hid within their nest;
But now do fly abroad with dreadful noise,
As if so many furies were awaked.
To arms then all that love your country's peace.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: How do ye mean my lord? or who are those
Your lordship shadows, underneath the name
Of swarming hornets?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Are you so dull offence?
And still so lulled in your security?
Whom should I mean, but bloody Danila,
And furious Alva his compeer in arms,
That fill the castle yard with their battalions,
And strive to take possession of your streets:
To arms then straight, if you will keep them back.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Is't like that Alva is revived again?

sp.speaker: 1 wife
sp.l: As like as he intends to take the town.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: But I suspect there is some treachery.

sp.speaker: 2 wife
sp.l: Will you believe his words, he doth but jest,
To try how we will take it if 'twere so.

sp.speaker: Champ.
sp.l: Nay by his looks and by his sudden haste,
It should appear the marks doth not jest.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: To arms to arms, o where's the governor?
Give order that your citizens prepare,
To stand upon their guard, defend themselves,
For whom you trusted, turns his weapons point
Upon your bosoms: all the Almaigne force,
Is quite revolted, and the enemy
Entering your streets: van end that damned slave,
Gives aid to Spain, and with his traitorous hand
Draws in destruction, if you look not to it.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Where are the Switzers should supply the trenches?

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: Drunk in their lodgings, and in reeling forth,
The Spaniards (Unresisted) murder them.
For honour's sake, for wretched Antwerp's sake,
Stand not amazed, but with courageous hearts,
And forward hands, fight for your liberty.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Are yet your eyelids open, are you yet
Awaked out of the slumber you were in?
Or will you still lie snorting in your sloth?
Be still persuaded you are safe enough?
Until the very instant, you do feel
Their naked swords glide through your weasond-pipes?
Or do you think with belching puffs that fly
From your full paunches, you can blow them back?
Or is the bottom of a deep carouse,
Able to drown them? will their fury melt
At the beholding of your dainty wives?
Or can submission be a stickler
In these hot braules? I tell ye burghers no,
fair words will be as oil to burning pitch;
And gold as sulphur to enkindled; flames,
Your daughter's chastity must quench their lust;
And your dear wives, 〈◊〉 their lawless arms:
I said as much but would not be believed,
Now tell me if I prophesied aright?
Or that my zealous words deserved rebuke?
Did I not say, the crocodile did weep,
But to obtain his prey? the sea look smooth,
But for a storm: would any thing be thought,
By the close confluence of the Spanish troops
Into the castle, but some massacre?
Yet was I rated to object as much,
Reviled and baffled for my loyalty:

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: I 〈◊〉 soldier, lean thy bitter words,
And help to fight for Antwerp's liberty.

sp.speaker: Stump.
sp.l: You have another groat to give me then,
I know your liberal minds will scorn t'impose,
The sweat of bloody danger on the brow
Of any man, but you'll reward him for it:
He shall at least (When he hath lost his limbs)
Be sent for harbour to a spittle-house.
How say ye, shall he not? Good reason then,
But we should venture; yes, to laugh at you,
Whilst we behold the Spaniard cut your throats:
An object base 〈◊〉 set a-work;
A sweaty cobbler, whose best industry,
Is but to clout a shoe, shall have his fee;
But let a soldier, that hath spent his blood,
Is lamed, 〈◊〉, or any way distressed,
Appeal for succour, than you look a sconce
As if you knew him not; respecting more
An ostler, or some drudge that rakes your kennels,
Than one that fighteth for the common wealth.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: It is thy country that doth bind thee to it,
Not any imposition we exact.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Binds me my country with no greater bonds,
Than for a groat to fight? Then for a groat,
To be enfeebled, or to lose a limb?
Poor groatsworth of effection; well, I'll learn
To pay my debt and to measure my desert
According to the rate: a groat I had,
And so much as a groat amounts unto you,
My sword shall pay ye in exchange of blows.

sp.speaker: Cham.
sp.l: Citizens how now?

sp.speaker: 1 citizen
sp.l: O monsieur champagne,
We are undone for want of discipline,

sp.speaker: 2 citizen
sp.l: The Spaniards hurry into every street,
What shall we do for safeguard of our lives?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: What shall ye do? stand every man at's door,
And take in's hand a Holbert or brown bill,
And study to defend him as he may.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.l: I hear them coming, let us shift away.

div.stage: In the alarum, Alva and Danila pursue Marquess hawrie, and count Egmont furiously.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Marquess d' Hawrie stay, thou canst not scape.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: And stay count Egmont: Danila's conquering sword,
Pursues thy life, therefore abide and yield it.

sp.speaker: Ma●
sp.l: Insatiate Alva, that like sun-rise ground,
Never sufficed with sweetest showers that fall,
But with a thousand mouths gapes still for more.
So thy desire of blood never satisfied,
With the rich tribute of so many lives,
Whose guiltless blood hath dyed poor Belgius' checks,
And changed her like a drunken bacchanal,
Still with a thousand quenchless appetites,
Dost thirst for more, as if that epithet
Were the sole object of thy hearts best hopes
know tyrant, marquess Hawrie flies thee not,
As fearing all the uttermost thou canst,
But the oppression of unequal power,
False treason, that betrayed our lives to thee,
And the sharp scourge, that fond security,
Hath justly thrown on Antwerp's wilfulness

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: These are the sluices that have brought on us,
The swelling pride and tyranny of Spain,
Which Antwerp careless off, although forewarned
By many bleeding instances about her,
Could not; nay, would not be advised at all.
Tell me but this, Alva and Danila both,
What state is there, be it ne'er so popular,
Abounding in the height of fortune's gifts;
And all felicities of worldly pomp,
That sees sad desolation sit in tears,
Upon her neighbour cities? wars keen edge,
Hath furrowed through their entrails, let them blood,
In every artery that maintaineth life,
Yet will not dread her danger to be near?
But warm her at their fires, sing at their sighs,
Revelling in her countless vanities,
As a perpetual date were set thereon.
Tell me I say, you that have seen all this,
And as devils, saints in the black calendar
Of wretchedst woe may truly be set down,
As authors of these sad confusions?
Do not you deem that state well worth the ills,
That this remissness brought upon the rest?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: They cannot but confess so much count Egmont.

sp.speaker: Eg,
sp.l: If this be granted what's your glory then?
An armed man to kill an naked soul:
A thousand sickles thrust into a field,
Of summer ripened and resistless corn:
A mighty tide to overrun a land;
Where no defence or bank to keep it back ▪
this is your honour, this their misery,
That are not conquered, but die wilfully.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: War taketh hold on all advantages.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What need advantage, where is no resist?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: So much the better, this is our discipline,
Therefore submit or die.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Not while I have a hand to lift my sword.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Nor you count Egmont?

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: Alva, nor I.
Egmont will with honour both live and die.

div.stage: The alarum again, and champagne is pursued in by Romero, Verdugo and Van end, where he is slain: so is the Marquess hawrie, and all engirting count Egmont, Alva steps to defend him, and they strike at him.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Hold when I bid ye; strike ye all at me?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Why stands thou then to guard an enemy?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Because I will, honour incites me to it,
The honour of this worthy nobleman,
And his high spirit even in the face of death.
Yield thee brave Egmont, Alva doth entreat thee,
In pity of thy bold adventurous youth,
And hopeful fortunes shining in thine eyes,
Thou seest these slain, yet will save thy life:
Thou seest me wounded to preserve thy life.
I that was never pitiful before,
Am forced to pity thee, what wouldst thou more?

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: Such pity Alva, as thou show'dst my father,
And noble horn, such thou intendest to me,
Therefore proceed and never pity me. They offer at him again

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Strike not I chargeve: come Egmont come,
Is wear that thou shalt yield; strike, spare me not,
Alas thou art too faint; come, yield thee now,
sp.stage: Striving to g●t again his weapons
sp.l: I'faith I will not hurt thee: so, have done,
Nay, no more weapons, thou art my prisoner.
And I will use thee very honourably.

sp.speaker: Egm.
sp.l: Alva, let forth my life, and then thou honourst me

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Not for the world, prisoner thou shalt to Spain,
And there be entertained to thy deserts.
Now pity, pack from Alua's heart again,
Against my nature once I looked on thee,
For this Count's sake: now to the deserts fly,
For havoc, spoil and murder now I cry.

div.stage: Champaigns wife hurried by two rascal solders.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Have mercy on a woman I beseech you,
As you are men and soldiers:
If you be Christians do not do me shame.

sp.speaker: 1 sold
sp.l: Search her.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: 'Zounds turn her inside outward.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Ransack her, every part of her.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: For manhood spare me.

sp.speaker: St●m.
sp.l: How nimbly death bestirs him everywhere ,
And I that am a weary of my life,
And would fain die I cannot,
Death is so proud he will not look on me,
These muddy rogues that hoarded up their coin,
Now have their throats cut for the coin they have:
They that for two pence would have seen me starve,
And still my old rotten stump and I,
Trot up and down as long as we can wag.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: As you are men ▪ be merciful to me.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Cast lots who shall have her.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: I'll give thee my share for thy part.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: I'll have my share in her.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Off with her jewels

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: How now, two soldiers ransacking a woman?
O 'tis Champaigns wife that was the governor,
Here is she, that would not have been seen
With a moth upon her, for a thousand pound;
That spent as much on monkeys, dogs and parrots,
As would have kept ten soldiers all the year.
Zblood I have seen her, where I have passed by her
In the streets, to stop her nose with her sweet gloves,
For fear my smell should have infected her;
And now I live to see her lugged, and torn
By lousy tottered rogues: oh Antwerp, Antwerp,
Now madam Marchpane, minx, your blows
And you are one.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Let's have her in the next corner.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Draw her along,

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Take that she has it is sufficient,
But go no further, it is inhuman to abuse a woman.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: What rogue art thou, dar'st speak unto a Spaniard?

sp.speaker: Stumpe.
sp.l: No rogue sir, but a soldier as you are,
And have had one leg more than I have now.
Sir, here's my passport, I have known the wars,
And have had the vantage of as fair a spoil as you have here.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Away you whoreson cripple rascal.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: You tottered shake-ragged rogues, what domineer you?
If Dalva's self were here, he should not do it.

div.stage: He draws his sword, kills one, and the other flies.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Good soldier, here's one jewel that they have not
That I do value at a thousand crowns,
I pray thee take it.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: What should I do with it, can you tell?
To have my throat cut for it, ha:
No, no your sister mince-pies groat
Will do me no pleasure now.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: For god's love, as you ever did respect a woman,
Help to convey me to some place of safety.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Where is it? not in Antwerp.
Your closet will not serve your turn,
You cannot walk to your garden-house.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: For god's sake help me as you are a man.

sp.speaker: Stump.
sp.l: Well, follow me, I'll do the best I can.

div.stage: A company of rascal soldiers came here pursuing the lady, he fights and bears her away from them all.
After a triumphant shout within, enter Alva, Danila, Romero, Verdugo, Van end, with their rapiers drawn, crying.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Victory, victory, Antwerp and victory.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: So valiant lords, this music likes me well,
Now may we boldly say the town is ours:
Yet sheath not your victorious swords awhile,
Till you have reaped the harvest of your pain,
In which pursuit, torture, exact and kill,
No less than in your fury you have done.
If the proud antwerpers (That do survive)
Lay not their treasure at your conquering feet.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Though no resistance anywhere appear,
Yet let not anger so decline with you
Be proud of victory, as well ye may,
Knowing the worth of your attained prize.
'Tis wealthy Antwerp you have won, and how?
Not by a lingering siege, of months or years,
But in a moment; entering at a leaven,
By two o'clock her haughty pride is shrunk,
And she in duty stoopeth to your will.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Can any here report the certain number,
Of those that have been slain during the conflict?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I had a note my lord, as I remember,
The number of the dead, by us cut off,
is seventeen thousand.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: But of our men,
How many fell there in this short assault?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Three hundred, or not many more my lord.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: For those three hundred, let ten thousand more,
Of this subiected city lose their lives,
Chain them together in the market place,
By hundreds and two hundreds ▪ and with shot,
Ring them about until they all be slain,
Spare neither widow, matron, not young maid,
Gray-bearded fathers, nor the babe that sucks.
One Spaniard's blood, I value better worth,
Than many hundreds of these drunken Dutch.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: First, if it please ye, quarter we the town,
That every one may know his privilege.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Well thought upon Verdugo: thus it shall be.
The burse, the statehouse, and the market place,
Belongs to me: the castle and that side,
To sancto Danila: on the other hand
The key, and water-port (Verdugo) is yours.
Saint George's port, and Kibdop, we assign
To lord Romeso: and for you Van end,
The North part of the city, Venus' street,
Remains the subject of desired spoil:
So lords, if I have well divided, speak;
If not, you shall be pleased before we part?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Your lordship hath discreetly cast our lots,
And for my part, I do accept of mine.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: So doth Romero.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: And Verdugo too.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: And I no less, than who is best content.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: About it then, be every one as quick,
In rifling of these rich burghers, as he was
In the assault: the world may talk of us,
As well for valour as our quick dispatch.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: My soldiers and myself will straight begin.

sp.speaker: Rom.
sp.l: And mine shall follow.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I'll not be behind.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: What will Verdugo?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Not be idle long,
But who are these so sawcily intrude?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Who are ye? speak, that like unbidden guests,
Dare tempt the patience of incensed Alva?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: We are of England (Castile's general)

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Of England are ye● what although you be,
Back slaves unto the door from whence ye came,
And on your knees solicit Alua's greatness:
If you do look for mercy at his hands.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Back when he bids you; now down upon your knees,
And crawl unto his presence to beg life.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Verdugo, drag him by the long tailed beard,
Alva doth scorn to wait upon their leisure.

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Come forward with a pox; now speak your mind,
And speak discreetly, lest you speak your last.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: This cruelty is more than we deserve,
And more than we expected would be shown.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Tax ye me then with cruelty so soon?
You shall have cause.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Nay hear them speak my lord.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: What can they say to shield themselves from death?

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: Nothing my lord if in your angry spleen
You have already passed your sentence on us:
But would the Duke of Alva cool his rage,
And mildly hear us: we would say my lord,
That England's league with Spain, King Phillip's word,
Passed to our gracious mistress, were enough
To warrant all the lives of any such,
As are her subjects in this wretched town:
And not their lives alone, but safe protection
Both for their goods and money: but if now
your highness hath commission to break
The holy contract which your King hath made,
We must be patient and abide the worst.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why what art thou that standst upon the league?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Governor (My lord) of the English house.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sirrah, you challenge the virtue of the league,
Yet understand not how the league is made.
So long as you converse not with the foes
Of royal Philip, nor withstand his right,
You are exempt the rigour of his scourge;
But being here, in this rebellious town,
You must partake the punishment they feel.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: We are not here great lord, to join with them
In any bold confederacy of war,
But for the traffic, which all nations else,
(As well as England) have within this place.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Why left ye not the city then, perceiving
We meant to call their duty to account?

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: We had no sign of any such intent.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You cannot so be quit nor so excused,
Therefore provide before tomorrow night,
To bring unto us forty thousand crowns,
For ransom of your house; or if you fail,
Both goods and lives shall all be forfeited:
So much we are content to yield unto,
Because we will not seem to break the league.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Alas my lord, 'tis more than (At this time)
Our goods and money will amount unto,
Considering that our credit (By this trouble)
Is quite cut off, with any of the city.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Shift as you can, I vow to have no less,
And at the appointed time.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Consider of it,
His favour's great in giving you such scope.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: So is the cat that dallieth with the mouse,
But in the end, her pastime is his death;
we must provide, the Spaniards thirst is great,
And better that we quench it with our gold,
Than let them swallow and carouse our bloods:
I prithee Godfrey try thy friends abroad,
And any money that thou hast bring forth,
That we may make the sum which he desires.

sp.speaker: God.
sp.l: I'll do the best I can, though hard it be,
To find a friend in this extremity.

div.stage: Enter Sancto Danila, an old citizen and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Let not your rough entreaty so molest,
The soul of him whose spirit already stoops,
Under the heavy burden of weak age;
You have my treasure, what more can you crave?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Thy 〈◊〉 so we please: there yet remains
A jewel of more worth than all thy wealth,
Which (Like a 〈◊〉) thou didst hide from us.
Thou hast a daughter, whom till we enjoy,
All 〈…〉 proceeds from us, sits here,
〈…〉 point of my scimitar;
〈…〉 speak?
〈…〉 in this tumult.
What 〈…〉 than her grave my lord,
Can be 〈◊〉 she hath?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Torture the slave,
His guileful heart, that studies to conceal,
My dear heart's treasure, shall be forced in sighs
To publish, what his stubborn tongue denies.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Thou hearst old fellow, trifle then no longer,
But show him where thy daughter doth abide.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Why pause ye on my bidding let him die,
That doubles with a Spaniard in his will.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Hear ye my lord.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Not any whispering noise,
Not any tittle, doth not bear the sound,
of beauty's sweet fruition to mine ears.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: My daughter lives, but not within the reach
Of my command: a nunnery in the arms
Of her religious peaceful privilege,
Doth clip her silly frighted virgin's life,
From whence my lord she cannot be recalled.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Bear art upon thy tongue, that may unlock
The gates of that in closed sanctuary,
And first entreat; but if entreaty fail,
Then use command; if neither will prevail,
Yet so thou shalt not cease, but in the cords
Of violent fury drag the damsel thence:
My soldiers shall attend to see it done,
That if, thou shrink, their weapons naked points,
May gorge thy sides, till thou bleed out thy life.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: I would that sacrifice might end this strife.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Away with him love faints through cold delay,
'Tis Danila speaks, and what he will he may.
Of whence are you?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Of England noble lord,
A factor to a London merchant here,
Who having tried my friends, and strained my purse,
To make my ransom: am now carrying it
To mighty Alva, to redeem my life.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: What value is it?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Full five hundred dollars.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Is this the utmost penny thou canst make?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: The length and depth of my ability.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: It will not serve to search thy chest for more
Or bide the torture we impose on such,
As cunningly, withhold what we demand.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: There is not in the world (That I may call
Rightly mine own) one stiver or one do●te,
More than is there comprised within th●● bag.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Give him the strappado; 〈…〉
out of your disjointed limbs other sums.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: The world doth know, my conscience and just heaven,
That there is all (At this time) I possess.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Save what is thrown into some hollow vault,
Or sunk into some well; or buried deep
sp.stage: Hoist him up and let him down again.
sp.l: Within the earth: so hoist the peasant up,
Now let him down; will ye confess as yet,
Where we may find the treasure you have hid?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: That which (My lord) is not, cannot be hid,
And to say that I know not, will but wrong
Your expectation, and deceive myself.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Let him rest my lord, it seems the wretch
Argues the troth, and this is all he hath.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Hence greedy beggar, hark (Peeled sheep)
Go hide thee in some bush, till waxing hours
Give thee another fleece to clothe thee with.
Yonder ariseth the bright morning star.
sp.stage: Enter an old citizen with his daughter.
sp.l: Whose rich resplendour gilds my happy thoughts,
And opens mines of treasure to my soul;
Welcome fair sweet, mine arms shall be thy throne,
Where seated once, mock death, and laugh to scorn,
The boisterous threats, of blood besprinkled war,
Who whilst he shows wild frisco's in the streets,
And with his gambols, overthrows huge buildings,
Mingle their tottered ruins, with the limbs
And clotted blood of many thousand souls:
Shall as an antic in thy sight appear,
Yielding no more occasion to be feared,
Than painted shapes of lions on a wall.

sp.speaker: Daug.
sp.l: Behold a virgin, whose distilling tears
Turn the dry dust to paste, where she doth kneel,
Behold the silver cognisance of age,
soiled with dissolving drops of sorrows rage:
If me you touch with a lascivious hand,
As from his eyes descends a flood of tears;
So will you draw a river from his heart,
Of his life's blood; both ways you shall obscure,
The honour of your name: if virgin I,
Or aged he, misdo by tyranny.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Let conquest satisfy, since in the strength
Of your successful power, our city vails,
And lies in prostrate duty at your feet:
Or if not conquest, be appeased with gold,
Which in abundance pleads for our release,
Only refrain, our conscience to wound,
With that, for which there is no physic found.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: I am impatient, she shall be my love,
Of all the spoils are reaped by painful war,
Blot beauty out, and what's our victory?
But as a banquet without company.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Arm you my lord, and to the fight again,
A crew of straggling soldiers (Lately vanquished)
Have gathered head, and in the heat of rage,
Give fresh assault: the leader to the rest,
Is a lame fellow that doth want a leg,
Who lays about him like a devil of hell.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: A troop of musket's guard this damsel hence,
And to my lodging see her safely brought,
Why stir ye not? environ her with shot,
Whilst we extinguish (With a shower of blood)
This late enkindled fire: be gone I say.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: It is impossible to pass the streets,
They are so pestered with this brainsick 〈◊〉:
And hark my lord, except you mount be time,
(The clamorous tumult draws so near this place,)
both you and we shall be surprised by them.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Is there no fortress near, nor house of strength,
Where I may leave my love, till this black cloud,
Of swollen hostility be overblown?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Not any (Good my lord) lead on your troops.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Then rather than another shall enjoy,
What Danila held esteemed in his eye,
Here it began, and here my love shall die.
Another stab her father, both combined,
By nature's laws, by nature's law shall end.

sp.speaker: Vaugh.
sp.l: Yet is not Antwerp quite bereft of life,
So long as we two breath, to stand for her,
Nor shall her ransack pass, without some right
Of just revenge: witness this last assault,
Wherein the scales of justice have been filled,
With (At the least) a hundred Spaniards lives,
That thought their victory to be secure.
But who are these? A burger, and with him
His tender daughter, having both sustained
The heavy stroke of death?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I knew them well.
They were my neighbours, ne●re unto the burf.

sp.speaker: Vau.
sp.l: Had these grey hairs retained the reverent worth
Of grave experience, as they might have done;
And had you been more rich in inward gifts,
And less magnificent in outward show,
Then had you lived, to die a natural death:
And you to see some of his honoured years.
But pride and luxury, have ever been,
The gate of misery, and nurse of sin:
Yet though you me contemned, I grieve your fall,
And will in pity, give you burial.

div.stage: Enter Lenchy and Martin two little children running.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor Lenchy, whether shall we go:

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: I cannot tell; come Martin let us hide us.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where is my father?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: He is in our house.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let us go thither?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: All the street is full of Spaniards; they have killed
Little Maria, and Hans Vanderbrooke.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ah whither shall we go?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Let's hide us here, no Spaniard will come hither.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay m. Hulder's orchard is hard by.
We'll get in there, and hide's among the trees,

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Come let us run.

div.stage: A great noise as they are going.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas the Spaniard's coming, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Alas poor Martin we shall both be killed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Alas poor Lenchy, kiss me pretty sister,
Now we must die.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Let's sit down here, and mart. I will clip thee in
Mine arms, they shall not see thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: But they will kill thee,
Alas where is my poor old father now, and my poor mother?

div.stage: Enter two Spaniards running, with their swords drawn.

sp.speaker: 1 Spa.
sp.l: Kill, kill, kill.

sp.speaker: 2 spa.
sp.l: Tue, tue, tue, tue.

sp.speaker: 1 Spa,
sp.l: Fuora villiaco.

sp.speaker: 2 spa.
sp.l: Follow, follow, follow, follow.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I pray you m. Spaniard hurt us not,
We are poor children, we have done no harm.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Good gaffer do not kill my little brother.

sp.speaker: 1 Spa.
sp.l: Fuora villiaco, sa, sa, sa, sa,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ah master Spaniard do not kill my sister,
My father is a poor blind man, and he will die,
if you kill her.

sp.speaker: 2 spa.
sp.l: Cut the bastard's throats.

div.stage: The children gets fast hold, and hang upon the Spaniards.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: O kill us not, we'll hang upon your arms,
Sweet gaffer, stay and look me in the face,
Have you the heart to kill a pretty girl?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good master Spaniard do not kill us,
Take any thing we have, but save our lives.

sp.speaker: 1 Spa.
sp.l: How the young brats cling about our swords?

sp.speaker: 2 spa.
sp.l: Zounds, dash out their brains.

div.stage: Enter old blind Harman and his wife.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Where are my children? Martin, Lenchy speak,
I heard you cry speak pretty souls, where are you?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Husband, Harman, whether will you go?
Alas you fall into the enemy's hands
For lack of sight.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: My children wife, my children, where are they?

sp.speaker: 1 Spa.
sp.l: Here you blind traitor, whether you shall go,
To your throat-cutting.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Here father, here, alas we shall be killed.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: O my sweet children,

sp.speaker: 2 Sp.
sp.l: Out you Brabant bitch, think you with whining
To preserve your whelps?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: O spare the infants ▪ and the aged blind,
These have not might, nor power to do you hurt.

sp.speaker: 1 Spa.
sp.l: Cut all their throats.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Kill us, but let our little children live.

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Help mother help, or else we shall be killed.

sp.speaker: Har. weeping.
sp.l: Hard hearted soldiers, where have you been bred?
Get honour on the proud resisting foe,
Myself have been a soldier as you are,
Now blind with age:
Old men, weak women, and poor wretched infants,
Should be respected in the heat of slaughter.
O do not this foul injury to arms;
Let my poor babies lead me to my grave,
Where are you my poor children?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Father, here.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Where art thou lenchy?

sp.speaker: Len.
sp.l: Here poor father.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Old as I am, and I have told this town;
That you should sack it, I did prophesy.

sp.speaker: 2 spa.
sp.l: Then prophet, didst thou prophesy of this?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Ah bloody Spaniard, that hast slain my children.

sp.speaker: 1 Spa.
sp.l: Bitch, art thou railing? take thou this.

sp.speaker: 2 spa.
sp.l: And this,
Get you together with your damned brats.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: O cruel Spaniard that dost spare no age nor sex,
Where art thou wife, and my poor little children?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Their blessed souls in Abraham's bosom rests,
Their bodies lie betwixt thyself and me,
By whom these pretty wretches were begotten,
Oh let me join my freezing lips to thine,
Now farewell Antwerp, say not we did fly,
Where with thy fall, old, young, and all must die.

div.stage: Enter Alva, English governor and soldiers.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Think ye to purchase freedom at this rate?
Some thriftless prodigal bestows in wine,
Or spends in dalliance on his courtesan,
Five thousand crowns: 〈◊〉 like your store affords
No greater plenty ▪ either from your chests,
That swell with surfeit of your avarice,
Rain down a larger shower of fruitful gold,
Or tender flowering pity, ne'er will spring.

sp.speaker: Governor
sp.l: I do protest (My lord) beside our plate,
And household furniture, this is the sum,
of all the wealth, at this time may be found
Within the english-house.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: And is not plate
Good boot for soldiers? have you that
And dare ye yet plead needy poverty?
Go fetch it me, or presently I'll send
A crew of such sharp carvers to your gate,
As shall anatomize your panting hearts,
To fill their conquering hands with wished spoils.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: The league with Engl. gave us better hope.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Talk nor of league nor England, nothing sound
In our wars music, that can please the sense;
Unless it have the cheerful sound of gold.
What's he? examine him: if he bring gold,
Free passage have he; but if empty be
The hollows of his hands; or cannot point
By demonstration, or express by speech,
Where it is fled, in this tempestuous storm,
That we by hugging it, may banish fear,
And burnish her pale cheeks with firmer red,
Let him have that belongs, the torturing cord.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Excuse my want, that have already paid
To sancto Danila, five hundred dollars.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Why not as much to me?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: I have it not,
Alas (My lord) consider of my state,
I am but factor for another man;
Yet of those goods committed to my charge,
Have I made bold (So much as I have said)
To free my life from further prejudice.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: How art thou free, when Alva is not fee'd?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: I hope (My lord) one ransom will suffice,
For one poor life.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: That ransom let me see.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: 'Tis paid (My lord) to sancto Danila.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: That which he hath is his, and none of mine,
Unless thou canst transform us, and of two
Make but one person: go to, trifle not,
But show me how I may be satisfied,
Or bide the peril that ensues thereon.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: More satisfaction than I have (My lord)
I cannot give, howe'er you torture me.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: That will we try, if rope and gibbet hold,
Let him endure the punishment, he needs
Will wilfully impose upon himself.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: O that you would at once with ruthless steel,
Carve up my breast, and let my blood suffice,
To quench your thirst for that I cannot give.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: So, let him down, stand off and give him air,
Speak now, and tell us where thy coin is hid?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Will ye believe me if I speak the truth?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: So it be truth which thou intends to speak.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: As I do hope this troubled soul of mine,
Which now is ready to forsake this flesh,
Shall find a resting place with my redeemer:
The coin you seek, and all the coin I have,
Lies in the coffers of proud Danila.

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Lie there and pine then, for deluding me.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Here comes another; many strokes (At last)
Cut down the strongest oak, much more, the tree
Hath but a few years growth, and that by storms,
And often whirlwinds shaken and decayed.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Hast thou been lately fallen into the hands
Of such as have had ryfling of thy purse?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: I have good sir.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: What art, a citizen?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Even what ye will, a miserable man.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: It seems, I come too late to profit by thee?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: You may imagine by my sick faint speech,
And by my faltring limbs distract and severed,
Whether I have been tortured, yea or no.

sp.speaker: Ve.
sp.l: Did they then torture thee for that thou hadst?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: They did and had it.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: Nothing then remains?

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: Nothing but this poor miserable life,
Which I would gladly were surrendered too.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.l: They for that thou hadst, did torture thee,
I see that thou hast not: here we'll put
A period to thy days. Hang him outright,
And so speed all, whose naked indigence,
Have not to feed Verdugo for expense.

sp.speaker: Factor
sp.l: My destiny, was to die this shameful death,
Which I accept with thanks to him that gives it,
And England now and London both farewell,
Let after times of Spanish rigour tell.

div.stage: Enter van end and a burgher's wife.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Thus will I feast myself with Antwerp's spoil,
And glut my pining soul with tragic acts,
Say pampered froe, where is thy treasure hid?
Speak truth, or breathe thy last upon this steel,
The bloody tempered torment of this town.
I'll batter down your pride from whence it came,
And with your ornaments adorn vast hell.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: Spare me van end I am a harmless woman,
Astonished unto death with frighting words,
Refrain thy deeds, and let the stronger sort,
Be miserable patients of thy wrath

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Pity prevails not, treasure is the fee,
That bribes the terror of my threatening breast;
And therefore speak, else hast thou spoke thy last.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Within that vault lies all my wretched wealth,
My gold my plate, my jewels all are there.

sp.speaker: Van.
sp.l: Then, there that heap of glory lies for me,
Which is the way?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: That is the cursed way,
Go thou accursed into that shade of hell,
The image of that everlasting night,
Where thy damned ghost must dwell exempt from light.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: What stir is here? what discontented rumor
Sends second message to my dull struck days,
Accustomed to the screeching yell of death?
Lady, what grievance? what is there to do?

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.l: O gentle soldier, heaven hath got me triumph,
Over that hellborn fury, damned van end,
That sold the beauty of this famous town:
And ravished Antwerp of her maiden joy.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: For god's sake let me come plague the dog,
I'll stone the Jew to death, and paint this vault
With the unhallowed blood of wicked treason:
Here, wear this weighty jewel in thy hat,
The town hath sent it for a token slave;
I bought this with the goat you gave me sir;
Soldier's must loathe despised ingratitude.
This woman for her ransom sends you this;
Give these two unto Charon for your passing.
And with this last, present grim Belzebub.
So sleep thy soul with princely Lucifer,
And take such fare as treason will afford.
Come lady, thus you see good friends must part,
Lament not for his loss his time was come,
And friends from friends, must either go or run.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: You see that all is lost, all spoiled and sacked,
what think you the best course to get away?

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Is there no place of strength, nor hope of safety ▪

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: No hope but death for three days being passed
Since the first entered; now being in cold blood,
The Spaniard is as hot in execution,
As the first hour he entered on the town.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Like maimed men let's pass out one by one,
The safest way and with the least suspect.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Dissevering of ourselves, and known for
Walloons, there's not a man of us shall pass the gates.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: And if we troop thus as we do together,
We shall be put to sword immediately.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: It were best to seek some low part of the wall,
On the moat side, and so escape by swimming.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: The courts of guard, and sentinels are kept,
And there's no hope of that.

sp.speaker: Stumpe.
sp.p: Hark you hark you, whether will you fly? I would know that; 'sblood whither? whether? ha; where will you be relieved? there's not a town dare receive you: the Spaniard has all the country; you cannot straggle a foot out of the walls, but your throats are cut; what have you to carry with you, but your scurvy notched limbs? you damned rogues, whether will you go, to feed wolves? A you whoreson rascals; and though these villanos burghers have (By their own security been the destruction of the city, a pox on them: yet it will be laid to our charge, because we were in it.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: By the mass the old lieutenant says true, it will be so indeed.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.p: You are all Walloons, but in the miserablest case that ever poor slaves were in: for you see, that if any man hate a man, call him but Wallon, the Spaniards cut his throat, what countryman soe'er he be ▪

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.p: Nay it is very true, it is most sure:

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.p: The Dutch on the other side, they hate you worse than devils, because the Spaniards entered where you kept the trenches.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.p: Villains do questionless, nay it is certain.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.p: What will you do then? here is my poor stump and I have stumbled through a thousand shot, and yet we halt together; there was never one poor piece of timber has been so singed as it has been: 'sblood it has been four times a fire under me, and yet we scramble together trotting, trotting: you'll be starved every mothers son of ye, and worried with dogs, and yet you'll fly.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: Why lieutenant Vaughan, what would ye have us do?

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.p: Die like men, what should we do, if there were any hope of safety but there is not, there is not.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.p: Lieutenant Vaughan, lead us, and we'll follow you to the death.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.p: We'll not forsake you to the last gasp.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.p: Yes, I'll halt before you, follow me as straight as you can ▪

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.p: Yes, and cut some of their throats before we die.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.p: They say the Spaniards and their whores are at dice upon the change: I'll lay my wooden leg afore them, cast at it who will; but who stands there?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: It is lieutenant Vaughan as I take it, lieutenant what news?

sp.speaker: S●um.
sp.p: What news quoth our captain! where have you been?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: I took the friary to escape the Spaniards.

sp.speaker: S●um.
sp.p:
Well, have seen the day captain, you 〈◊〉 rather been a cutting throats, then at a mass, 'twas not devotion
drave you to the place: so captain, captain, the world is turned: do you remember the groat they offered me, when you came to train soldiers? ha, give him a groat? ha, ha, I have since that seen their mistress's 〈…〉 by a lousy lackey, as naked as a new shaved water-dog: and lord why went you to the friary? why to the friary?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.p: What should I do when the poor Walloons fighting at the trenches,
sp.l: The Spaniards entering on the counterscarp,
Had not a soldier sent to second them.
The great swollen bellied burghers get brown bills,
As to drive rascal beggars from their doors;
The madding people so amazed with fear,
That turning head with every little noise,
Stopped up the entrance of the streets with throngs,
That when count Egmont, Hawry and the rest,
Called to the burghers for supplies of men,
The uncertain murmur of the multitude,
Increased but the confusion of the town:
The villainous and dastard recreant Almains,
Kneel to the Spaniards, casting down their arms.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.p: A those Almains, those Almains, they cried live Spaniards: a vengeance take them, they were called high Almains, but they are low enough now; for a number of them are cut off by the waste: you may call them blanched Almains and you will, for their guts are blanched about their heels.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: By these disorders of witless townsmen,
Perceiving that the Spaniards would prevail;
What should I do but shift to save my life?

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: Captain. your life's in as great danger now as ere it was,
The Spaniard is as cruel in cold blood as ere he was;
Oh captain, captain, where is Antwerp now?
It 〈◊〉 my native place, where should I then be free,
If made a slave, where I was freely born?
There's not a town almost in Brabant now,
That gives a man the safety of a night:
What should we then do living:
Have you and I seen that, that we have seen,
And come to this?
If you reserve the courage you were wont,
Of a brave soldier and a gentleman,
Let's do something yet worthy the talking of,
I have won a company of poor hurt soldiers,
Yet able to wield weapons and to fight.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: And we will follow you, live or die:

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Love life and love death.

sp.speaker: 3 soldier
sp.l: Through Alva's quarter.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Why bravely spoke,
If you will take such part then as we do,
Help me to lead these straggling companies,
And we'll amongst their quarters ere we die.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: My hand and heart, and do engage my soul.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: Why then come lads; why this is resolved like men,
If we must go, we'll go together then.

div.stage: Enter two soldiers leading in the fat Burger in a Cord.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Confess ye slave where thou hast hid thy money,
Or we will hang thee on a gibbet straight.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That ever I was born; gentlemen believe me,
I have no more than what I told you of,
Some thousand gilders in my counting house.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: You have no more than?

sp.speaker: Burg.
sp.l: Not as I have faith
To God, and to the safety of my country.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Then hang him presently.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Nay courteous gentlemen,
As you are Spaniards famous for your acts,
Let me not die.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: The rogue would flatter us,
S●●ra, imagine 'tis too weak a key,
To tune our hearts to; when the cries of babes,
Screeks of distressed women and old men,
Have not prevailed to qualify our rage:
Let us dispatch him.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Gentlemen, but hear me.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: If thou canst tell us where thy treasure's hid,
Or else for ever let thy lips be dumb.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Alas would ye have me lie?

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Stay fellow soldier,
I have bethought me of a pretty trick,
To sift this butterbox a better way:
We will tie him by the thumbs unto this post,
And tickle him until he do confess.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Content i'faith, so at the least, suppose
We get no money yet we shall have sport.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Nay gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: Sirrah, apply your wits,
Or with my sword I'll hack your filchers off.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: O that I were in'th bottom of my seller.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Is thy money hidden there? speak?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: No truly sir,
But then I hope I should not hang byth' thumbs.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: He dallies with us, tickle him a good.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: O God, God, what shall I do, sweet gentlemen.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Confess then, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: O lord I shall sound,
By these ten ends, I have nor plate nor coin,
Your general and countrymen have all.

div.stage: Alarum, enter stump and captain, the Spaniards fly.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What 〈◊〉 we here, a burger tied byth' thumbs?

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: It is the tallow-cake, the rammish fat,
That would not give a penny to a soldier,
I know him well; now sir how feel yourself ▪

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: O gentlemen never so much distressed.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Your greasy paunch will not defend you then?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Not from these Spaniards, they 〈…〉 think,
Nay far more covetous than devils of hell.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: You cannot satisfy them with a groat,
But if I should requite thy vild contempt,
Here should I leave thee, that as thy treasure
Has been a prey to their devouring lust,
So in this dunghill of thy carrion flesh,
Their ravenous swords might find a dirty feast,
For naught but draff art thou composed of.
Nor fit for any thing but to feed worms,
Yet thou shalt find a difference twixt my thoughts
And the base temper of thy muddy mind:
Go live, if thou canst scape their bloody hands,
Till want and beggary cut short thy days.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I thank you sir; I have (For all their threats)
One bag of dollars cast into a well,
And that I'll give ye for this friendly succour.

sp.speaker: Stu.
sp.l: Hence tumbril from my sight, when bounty might
Have calmed my sharp affliction than thy hand
Was fast closed up; but now it is too late,
Thou wouldst seem prodigal, away base churl.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Let me entreat you sir, to take that sum,
My heart repents me much, for what is passed.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Guts, trouble me no more.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: The lord preserve you sir,
Surely you seem an honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: Wilt thou leave off thy prating and be gone?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: With all my heart sir, and I thank you too.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: How like Leviathan, his clumsy limbs
Walk not but tumble, that sad common wealth,
Nurseth such drones to suck her honey up,
In time of need shall find as small supply,
As he hath been to Antwerp's wretchedness:
but valiant soldier, what is now to do?

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: What, but to hunt the footsteps of pale death,
Until we rouse him in his sooty cave,
There, will no prospect of our countries fall,
Offend our eyesight; there no treachery
Of haughty Spaniards tread a bloody march;
Nor any base objection of ingrate,
And thankless citizens sit in our doors:
But we shall quietly enjoy the peace,
For which we breathe; there shall we be secure,
There free from thought of this world's misery,
And there indeed find true felicity:
For there our travel shall be recompensed,
Our love requited, and our wounds repaid
With double merit. Haste then unto the place,
Upon the earth is nothing but disgrace.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I fly with thee true honourable mind,
And we together will that mansion find.

div.stage: Alarum and excursions, enter stump and captain, bloody and wounded.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: See captain, now I have it on my breast,
The honourable cognisance of death,
This purple river, from this weeping fount,
More glads and quickens my decayed spirit,
Than ever Christ all spring in heat of summer:
The weary traveller, his strength revives,
To draw out tedious hours still on earth,
But mine doth flourish to possess, anon
The blessed haven of eternity.

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: I trust I shall be there with as much speed,
My passport (I do think) the Spaniards
Has sealed as deeply, and my journey laid
With no less easy travel to be there.
See, if thy bleeding wounds can speak to me,
mine can as fast make answer unto thine.

sp.speaker: Stum.
sp.l: Let me embrace this sweet affinity,
Like in our lives agreeing in our deaths:
But what do I behold? thine eyelids faint,
And the warm touch of thy desired cheek,
Begins to freeze; wilt thou anticipate
Those joys before me? gentle captain slay,
There's but a minute that divides our hopes:
O he is dead, may his departing soul,
Usher my spirit above those fleeting clouds:
Death, why delayest thou? set thy lazy hand
To the divorcement of my loathed flesh.
I am prepared, my penitent sad thoughts,
Have long ago washed my contagious sin:
The blood that I have spilt (The massacres
Procured and practised by this hand of mine)
Heaven lay not to my charge; for though my sword
Was never drawn but in a rightful cause,
Yet much misprision hath attended it;
That, and all else, this sigh craves pardon for,
Mine eyes were near accustomed to tears,
Let it suffice, these wounds do weep for them:
Antwerp farewell, if thou have done me wrong,
This latest gasp, sends pardon from my tongue.

div.stage: Enter in triumph, with drum, colours and soldiers, Sancto Danila.

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Now war hath wrapped his bloody colours up,
And sheathed his fatal sword with his, we ours,
Prefixing truce to our laborious arms;
This city late of christening the fame,
For wealth and glory: now remains the map,
〈◊〉 destruction and perpetual ruin;
〈…〉 with slaughtered carcases,
〈…〉 before were stuffed with pride,
An left as 〈…〉:
o in remorse of human clemency,
My heart (Not thinks) could sigh, my eyes shed tears,
To call to mind and see their misery:
But they were wanton and lascivious,
Too much addicted to their private lust:
And that concludes their martyrdom was just.
Hold, one of you, convey this serious letter
To warlike Alva, tell him as he willed,
After my forces lodged in garrison,
I'll meet his grace at bridges, and from thence
Acquaint the court of Spain with our success;
Pray God the tyranny expressed in Antwerp,
Like to the echoing clamour of a trumpet,
Speak not our deeds before our own approach.

sp.speaker: 1 soldier
sp.l: My lord, behold where lie the mangled bodies
Of those two fierce assailing Brabanters,
That all this while kept us at such a bay,
And when we thought the town was won, procured
So great a deluge of Iberian blood.

sp.speaker: 2 soldier
sp.l: Let's drag them at our horses tails my lord,
And as we pass through every town and village,
Make them example to the world for pride?

sp.speaker: Dan.
sp.l: Who toucheth them but in disgrace, my sword
Shall lop his arm off ▪ were they proud sayst thou?
Their pride was honourable, deserving love
Rather than hate; nay should we do them right,
Had they been strengthened with convenient aid
We had been beaten from the town again
And made exchange of conquest: which subdued
There never lived two 〈◊〉 heroieth spirits
That for their country have deserved as much
To be renowned; as ever 〈◊〉 was
Or Roman 〈◊〉 or the 〈…〉
They for their 〈◊〉 could but lose their lives
These have inequal service done as much
Take up their bodies; of ten thousand others
rest by our swords, and left unburied
These two will we in person see interred,
And do them right, the law of arms requires;
So march we hence, striking a mournful sound
Till we have said our honoured foes in ground

sp.speaker: Time
sp.l: Thus worldlings, time in his unwonted love
Hath stayed his course, to rub the memory
Of actions long since cast behind his back
His care is fruitful, and doth wish to see
No heavy or disastrous chance befall
The sons of men if they will warned be
But when they 〈◊〉 against my discipline
Wasting the treasure of my precious hour
No marvel then, like misery catch hold
On them, did fasten o this woeful town
Whose bleeding fortune, whose lamenting 〈◊〉
Whose streets besmeared with blood, whose blubbered eyes
Whose tottered walls, whose buildings overthrown
Whose riches lost, and poverty made known:
May be a mean all cities to affright
How they in sin and pleasure take delight

div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
